text_raw: But although we subsequently fretted about the vulnerabilities building up within the global financial system as a result of the relaxed attitude to risk and the easy availability of credit, we never imagined quite how extreme the unwinding would prove, particularly after the bankruptcy of Lehman's last September triggered a near collapse of the financial system and a world-wide plunge in business and consumer confidence.

text_clean: over the course of the past year the term of trade between the state and the bank have ﻿1 swing decisively one way and then the other

text_raw: For the majority of this period, the state was reliant on the deep pockets of the banks to finance periodic fiscal crises.
text_clean: for the majority of this period the state be reliant on the deep pocket of the bank to finance periodic fiscal crisis

text_raw: But for at least the past century the pendulum has swung back, with the state often needing to dig deep to keep crisis-prone banks afloat.

text_raw: Events of the past two years have tested even the deep pockets of many states.
text_clean: event of the past two year have test even the deep pocket of many state

text_raw: In so doing, they have added momentum to the century-long pendulum swing.
text_clean: in so do they have add momentum to the century long pendulum swing

text_raw: Reversing direction will not be easy.

text_raw: It is likely to require a financial sector reform effort every bit as radical as followed the Great Depression.

text_raw: It is an open question whether reform efforts to date, while slowing the swing, can bring about that change of direction.

text_raw: Paul Tucker: The crisis management menu Speech by Mr Paul Tucker, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability at the Bank of England, at the SUERF, CEPS and Belgian Financial Forum Conference: Crisis Management at the Cross-Roads, Brussels, 16 November 2009.
text_clean: paul tucker the crisis management menu speech by mr paul tucker deputy governor for financial stability at the bank of england at the suerf cep and belgian financial forum conference crisis management at the cross road brussels november

text_raw: It is a great pleasure to be here today.
text_clean: it be a great pleasure to be here today

text_raw: The current crisis has thrown up so many lessons in so many dimensions of the rules of the game for the financial system, that I congratulate the organisers on devoting a whole conference to crisis management.
text_clean: the current crisis have throw up so many lesson in so many dimension of the rule of the game for the financial system that i congratulate the organiser on devote a whole conference to crisis management

text_raw: That in itself is a meaty enterprise.
text_clean: that in itself be a meaty enterprise

text_raw: But a vital one.
text_clean: but a vital one

text_raw: By way of setting the scene for todays conference, I will offer the Bank of Englands perspective on the various components of a crisis management package: central bank liquidity insurance for viable firms and markets; firm recovery plans, and contingent capital; resolution plans for winding down failed businesses, including payouts from depositinsurance regimes; and official-sector support operations, including emergency liquidity assistance and Capital of Last Resort.

text_raw: Every countrys authorities need a policy on each of these components, because some day in the future our successors will find that, however good, the improvements our generation makes in the structure, regulation and supervision of the financial system will let them down.

text_raw: A thread that runs through the discussion is how to preserve the core financial services provided to the economy through periods of extreme stress without bailing out banks equity holders or uninsured wholesale creditors.

text_raw: That is the essence of the Too Big/Important To Fail debate.
text_clean: that be the essence of the too big important to fail debate

text_raw: It is not so much that the top management of banks consciously swing for the fences, but rather that wholesale credit may be systematically too cheap for banks, and perhaps other intermediaries too, unless the usual market disciplines of failure can apply.
text_clean: it be not so much that the top management of bank consciously swing for the fence but rather that wholesale credit may be systematically too cheap for bank and perhaps other intermediary too unless the usual market discipline of failure can apply

text_raw: The international community is, rightly, increasingly focused on this.

text_raw: Central bank liquidity insurance: discount window lending against wide collateral I shall begin with the central bankers role as lender of last resort, the one area where there was quite a lot of thinking ahead of this current crisis.

text_raw: Even so, one of the things many central banks, including the Bank of England, confronted over the past two years or so was that, when conditions are bad enough, the central bank will inevitably lend to solvent and viable firms against a very wide range of collateral.

text_raw: Since we will end up doing so, it is wise to acknowledge that in advance.

text_clean: but crucially it be also wise to set the term so a to avoid subsidise or encourage imprudent liquidity management by firm in normal circumstance

text_raw: That is one of the principles which underpin the Bank of Englands own new, permanent liquidity facilities introduced just over a year ago.
